text:
45 year old woman admitted to T/SICU from the OR following a
   transsternal T4 vertebrectomy and mass removal. Pt. with alcoholic
   cirrhosis and had 5L blood loss in OR.
   PMH:
   Hx DM2, CRI, ETOH abuse, pancreatitis, and cirrhosis, depression who
   was admitted on [**2130-4-27**]  with new acute low back pain w/ bilateral leg
   spasms, and was found on CTA to have T4 vertebral body destruction. Pt
   was seen on [**2130-4-22**] at OSH for atypical chest pain with negative cardiac
   eval. One day later after discharge, she re-presented to OSH with
   mid-low back pain. Pt was also recently discharged from [**Hospital 1711**]
   Hospital ([**Date range (2) 6007**]?) for ETOH detoxification.  Attempts to biopsy
   area and resect using posterior approach were abandoned as pt. could
   not tolerate prone position.
   T4 vertebrectomy via transsternal approach
   Assessment:
   Long OR course with large blood loss.  Arrived sedated on propofol and
   requiring neo for BP maintenance. Two right sided chest tubes with
   large sanginous output to water seal. Multiple areas of ecchymosis
   especially on back and perineal area. Last hct 35, INR 1.6.  Sternal/R
   thoracotomy incision closed with dermabond, open to air. Intubated.
   Lumbar drain in place without drainage. Lactate 2.9.
   Action:
   Q 1-2 hour neuro checks done, thoracic CT obtain, CXR X 2 done,
   frequent lab draws, 2 units prbc, 2 units ffp, bag of platelets given.
   Q 1 hour chest tube output recorded and patency ensured.  Lumbar drain
   positioned in effort to obtain 15cc CSF output q 1 hour. Dr [**First Name (STitle) **]
   assessed drain patency at 01:00.
   Response:
   Awakes to name while on low dose propofol, follows commands but gets
   agitated and clamps on endotracheal tube. Follow commands readily with
   arms, wiggles l toes and withdraws R leg to pain. CT output slowed,
   continued to require low dose neo. Initially lumbar drain did not
   drain, now with 12cc/hr when level at -5 cm below shoulder.
   Plan:
   Continue to monitor neuro status, ct output, labs.  Consider weaning to
   extubation when stabilized.
   Coagulopathy ..pt with alcohol cirrhosis
   Assessment:
   Large abdomen with ascities.  Hct 22, INR 1.6, platelets down to 80
   multiple areas of ecchymosis and oozing from central lines. Large CT
   output
   Action:
   PRBCs X 2 given, 2 units ffp, 1 bag of platelets. Frequent lab
   monitoring.
   Response:
   Decrease in CT output, less oozing from central lines, stabilizing
   hemodynamics
   Plan:
   Continue to monitor closely.
   Pain control (acute pain, chronic pain)
   Assessment:
   Large thoracic/sternal incision. Initially on propofol only.  Was
   previously on neurontin and Dilaudid for back pain.
   Action:
   Pain assessment q 2-4 hours, fentanyl iv as well as repositioning for
   pain reduction
   Response:
   Pt. nods that pain is acceptable. Because of intubated status, unable
   to use pain scale.
   Plan:
   Continue frequent assessment. Judicious use of narcotics as indicated
   combined with positioning techniques. Restart adjunctive pain measures
   today (lidocaine patch and neurontin). When extubated, consider
   switching to PCA medication.
